    • 0:43:54But what we want to start to think about as we start to build web applications,

    • 0:44:05we're building our web applications.

    • 0:46:26actually as an attribute of these h1 elements.

    • 0:46:37inside of the style element, where I've said for every h1 element,
    • 0:46:42here's how you should style it.

    • 0:46:55And that is then going to apply to all of the h1 elements
    • 0:46:58that my web page happens to find inside the body of my web page.
    • 0:47:02So there's a couple of advantages here.
    • 0:47:04Advantage number one is what we talked about a moment ago.
    • 0:47:06I don't need to duplicate the same code in both of these h1 elements.

    • 1:11:41So dot Baz, in this case, is going to style only the elements that
    • 1:11:46have a class of Baz.

    • 1:12:10headings, those do get styled as blue.
    • 1:12:12But the third heading does not, because I've

    • 1:12:17applied to this third element there.
    • 1:12:20So oftentimes, it can be very helpful if you

    • 1:12:26might be styled in some ways and other elements that might be styled similarly

    • 1:12:45as well.

    • 1:13:27but I should style element Foo in another way.

    • 1:13:35And in order to deal with that we have to start
    • 1:13:37to deal with the CSS problem of specificity, of what happens when
    • 1:13:41I have multiple different CSS selectors that could apply to the exact same HTML
    • 1:13:47element?
    • 1:13:47And this often happens when we start to add IDs and classes to our elements
    • 1:13:53as well.
    • 1:13:54So when we deal with specificity, specificity goes in a particular order.
    • 1:13:58There's an order of precedence that we can
    • 1:14:00follow for determining what style should ultimately
    • 1:14:03be applied to any particular element.
    • 1:14:06The first, most powerful--
    • 1:14:08most specific way of referencing an element is inline styling, literally
    • 1:14:12adding a style equals attribute to our HTML elements
    • 1:14:16in the way we did way at the beginning when
    • 1:14:18we were first taking a look at CSS.
    • 1:14:20If we associate inline styling with an HTML element, that's
    • 1:14:24going to take precedence over any styling that's inside the style
    • 1:14:27section of our head of the web page or inside of a separate dot CSS file,
    • 1:14:32because the reasoning goes, if you are literally putting the style
    • 1:14:36code attached to the element itself, then we probably
    • 1:14:39want to apply it to that element.
    • 1:14:42After that, specificity goes in order of how precisely we
    • 1:14:47are identifying an element.
    • 1:14:49An ID is a unique way to identify an element.
    • 1:14:51There is only one element with that particular ID.
    • 1:14:54So if I've added style to a particular ID,
    • 1:14:57that is going to be pretty highly valued in terms of how specific it is.
    • 1:15:01Next, we look at classes.
    • 1:15:03So if there's no ID selector, we look for,
    • 1:15:05did we reference the element by its class?
    • 1:15:08And if so, then that takes next precedence.
    • 1:15:11And otherwise, then we fall back to what type of HTML element it is.
    • 1:15:15Is it an h1?
    • 1:15:16Is it an ordered list?
    • 1:15:17Is it a table?
    • 1:15:18So in short, the type is the least specific.
    • 1:15:21Class is slightly more specific.
    • 1:15:23ID is more than that.
    • 1:15:24And the most specificity we can provide is by literally putting the CSS inline
    • 1:15:29with the HTML element itself.
    • 1:15:31So let's take a look at an example of this.

    • 1:15:37have a div, whose ID is Foo, inside of which I'm just saying the word hello.

    • 1:16:01Well, because ID has higher specificity than just an individual tag,
    • 1:16:06well, then next, what we're going to say is that this Hello is going to show up
    • 1:16:09is red.

    • 1:16:12And so this element is going to show up red instead.
    • 1:16:15And it doesn't matter what order these are in.
    • 1:16:17It's not that the later one takes precedence.

    • 1:16:24is in that order, it's still going to show up as red, because this ID
    • 1:16:28selector is more specific than just the name div, which is the name of the HTML
    • 1:16:35element that happens to be there.
    • 1:16:37And so as you start to develop more sophisticated style sheets,
    • 1:16:40you might find that some of your CSS code

    • 1:16:46rules work to know as you add style to your elements

    • 1:22:37been very specific about picking an attribute

    • 1:22:45And we can use CSS selectors in more powerful ways too, maybe not just
    • 1:22:49to style a particular element always, but to style

    • 1:24:59All right, so now we've seen how we can use various different CSS
    • 1:25:02selectors to very precisely define how we want our web pages to be styled.
    • 1:25:07But one other thing we can use CSS for that's quite powerful
    • 1:25:09is responsive design.
    • 1:25:11And responsive design is all about making sure
    • 1:25:14that our web pages look good, no matter how you're looking at the web page.
    • 1:25:17Nowadays, people aren't always looking at web pages on their computers.
    • 1:25:20But they're looking at web pages on their mobile phones or on their tablets
    • 1:25:23as well.
    • 1:25:24And it's important as we begin to design web pages that we design our web
    • 1:25:27pages in a responsive way.
    • 1:25:29So we'll look at a number of different ways
    • 1:25:31we can implement responsive design in our web pages,
    • 1:25:35starting with the discussion of the viewport.
    • 1:25:38And what the viewport is is the viewport is the visual part of the screen
    • 1:25:42that the user can actually see.
    • 1:25:44So the viewport is this entire area of the web page
    • 1:25:47that displays content to the user.
    • 1:25:50So one question you might ask is, what's going to happen when you take this page
    • 1:25:53and translate it onto a mobile screen?
    • 1:25:56Well, one thing that many mobile devices do by default
    • 1:25:59is treat their viewport as though it is the same width as a computer screen.
    • 1:26:04Because not all web pages are optimized from all device mobile devices,
    • 1:26:08you want to make sure that on a mobile device you can see everything.
    • 1:26:10And so many phones will take a web page like this
    • 1:26:14and just shrink it down to fit onto a mobile screen that
    • 1:26:17looks a little something like that.
    • 1:26:19Now, of course, that's probably not really what we want it to look like.
    • 1:26:22Ideally, we want our page to adapt to different sized screens.
    • 1:26:26Maybe we want the heading and the image and the text,
    • 1:26:28if that's what these are, to grow a little bit to fill that entire screen.
    • 1:26:33And so one simple thing we can do is just to add a little line of code
    • 1:26:37to our HTML inside the head section of our page that controls the viewport.
    • 1:26:42This line of code here is providing some metadata to our HTML page and saying,
    • 1:26:47I would like you to change the viewport to be
    • 1:26:49specifically the width of the device.
    • 1:26:53By default, many phones will use a viewport that's actually
    • 1:26:55wider than the width of the device, treat
    • 1:26:57it as if they're loading a page in a computer,
    • 1:26:59and then shrinking it down to the size of a mobile device.
    • 1:27:02If you and your web page specify, though,
    • 1:27:04that you want the viewport to be just the device width,
    • 1:27:07oftentimes a page is going to look a whole lot better on a mobile device.
    • 1:27:12But in addition to just adding a line like this,
    • 1:27:14there are other actual changes we can make
    • 1:27:16to our page to make it look a little better on different screens.
    • 1:27:20And one of those has to do with media queries.
    • 1:27:22And media queries are all about controlling
    • 1:27:25how our page is going to look depending on how we render that particular page,
    • 1:27:30or what size screen we're rendering that page on.
    • 1:27:32So let's take a look at an example of how
    • 1:27:34we might go about using media queries in order
    • 1:27:38to control what a page actually looks like depending on what type of page
    • 1:27:43or what type of browser we're using to view it.
    • 1:27:46So I'll go ahead and open a new file that I'll call responsive.html,
    • 1:27:50because we're going to try and build a responsive web page now.
    • 1:27:53And now, I'll go ahead and inside the body of my page
    • 1:27:56just include a big heading that says Welcome to My Web Page, for example.
    • 1:28:02And just to demonstrate what you can do now with responsive design
    • 1:28:06is I could say something like, let me add a style tag here,
    • 1:28:10where I want to say that if the size of the screen is a certain width,
    • 1:28:15then I want to style the page in one way.
    • 1:28:17And if the size of the page is a different width,
    • 1:28:19then I might want to style the page in a different way.
    • 1:28:22You might imagine that as you shrink the screen
    • 1:28:23you want to move elements around in order
    • 1:28:25to rearrange them to make the page just look a little bit nicer
    • 1:28:28on a mobile screen.
    • 1:28:29So we'll do a very simple example of just changing the color depending
    • 1:28:33on the size of the screen.
    • 1:28:35So let me specify now in a media query.
    • 1:28:38And the syntax for media query looks like this.
    • 1:28:40I'm going to use the @ symbol and say media and then
    • 1:28:43specify for what type of media I would like to apply this query.
    • 1:28:48I can say something like, if the minimum width of the page
    • 1:28:52is 600 pixels, in other words, if the width of the page
    • 1:28:54is 600 pixels or anything larger than 600 pixels, well,
    • 1:28:59then go ahead and take the body and give it a background color of red.
    • 1:29:06But then I could also add another media query and say,
    • 1:29:09you know what, for this media query let me give it a max width of 599 pixels,
    • 1:29:14meaning if the size of the screen is 599 pixels or fewer,
    • 1:29:19then maybe I'd like to take the body and give it a background color of blue,
    • 1:29:24for example.
    • 1:29:26So now let's take a look at what happens when I take this page
    • 1:29:29and actually open it and see what's going on.
    • 1:29:31I'll open up responsive.html.
    • 1:29:34And here's what I see normally.
    • 1:29:35I see a red web page, because my screen is longer than 600 pixels wide.
    • 1:29:40But notice what happens as a shrink this web page.
    • 1:29:42If I go ahead and shrink it, looking at it on a smaller screen,
    • 1:29:46eventually it turns to blue.
    • 1:29:48If it's above 600 pixels wide, it's going to be red.
    • 1:29:51If it's below 600 pixels wide, the color changes to blue.
    • 1:29:56So we're able to now use these media queries to really fine tune control
    • 1:29:59how our page is going to look on various different types of devices.
    • 1:30:03If it's on a big screen, maybe you want the elements to look a certain way.
    • 1:30:07If it's a smaller screen, maybe they'll look differently.
    • 1:30:09And you don't just need to control a background color.
    • 1:30:11You can control any CSS property you want just by using these media queries.
    • 1:30:16You can say on a big screen, you want certain amounts of spacing or padding.
    • 1:30:19You can even hide elements on smaller screens
    • 1:30:21if you want to by using a particular CSS property called the display property.
    • 1:30:26That controls whether or not an element is even visible.
    • 1:30:29And ultimately put together, this can help to make your pages a little bit
    • 1:30:32more responsive.
    • 1:30:34And there are a number of different media
    • 1:30:35queries that we can apply to our page as well.
    • 1:30:37We can check to see whether a mobile device is vertical or landscape.
    • 1:30:41We can check to see whether the user is viewing the page on their computer
    • 1:30:44screen or if they've tried to print out the contents of the page as well.
    • 1:30:48So there are a number of different options
    • 1:30:50that we have to really control how a page is going to look.
    • 1:30:54There are some other tools we have in our toolbox as well, though,
